CD985C78CB74400DB8AF21373AE83850.description: Create various representations of data, including with technology, to interpret frequency.

D86A4165584142F9B69766F5589080C6.description: Discuss potential categories for open-ended questions and closed-list questions in relation to the same statistical question.

55073F65469F4CBE965303007918FAFD.description: Justify possible answers to a statistical question using mode.

D9495D12901E4E2F973B7A8B1EEB2E53.description: Recognize data sets with no mode, one mode, or multiple modes.

929A249E382848AE9D96347E2AF78DF3.description: Identify the mode in various representations of data.

B5BE920682214DEC8E00D501180E3C96.description: Determine frequency for each category of a set of data by counting individual data points.

8824FEBC10E04B59A62C9D35DCCD187C.description: Examine categorized data in tables and graphs.

FACB46688F584CC0BBA1B61E3DD48D93.description: Frequency can be represented in various forms.

6BE03CE67CF147B4A6249DD6AB37EB5E.description: Frequency can be used to summarize data.

CC26758FB87842278639C786C0B6D46B.description: Frequency can be a count of categorized responses to a question.

531E45719EB24B81AFC4FBB6978294D7.description: Frequency is a count of categorized data, but it is not the data value itself.

B4D9A30F464C45818E6B6A84357A4808.description: Representations of frequency can include bar graphs dot plots, stem-and-leaf plots.

345112910F2F40D0A237F44A6541F318.description: Responses can be categorized in various ways.

C43B66D8613D45C3A58F98CA28D56D43.description: Closed-list questions provide a list of possible responses to choose from.

F61C205DF4B040069EAFDFF998051B40.description: Data can be collected by asking closed-list and open-ended questions.

7127F76B92A3405993C21D679EE96AD7.description: The mode is the category with the highest frequency.

6AB02CD2F34A4242BF3E7854ECB5D27A.description: Frequency can be compared across categories to answer statistical questions.

627681BD6D96452E8B5A5C0C81C1EFD1.description: Students analyze frequency in categorical data.

B256F0015B9447BBAB74AFAF0EF29B48.description: Statistics: The science of collecting, analyzing, visualizing, and interpreting data can inform understanding and decision making.

D06301C6350B415991FFFE71B969C46E.description: Solve problems involving an arithmetic sequence.

4EE3F02FEBC94236909C17067E752D69.description: Determine the missing term in an arithmetic sequence that corresponds to a given position.

EDDA4025D2F0462EA48125819BB9B291.description: Write an algebraic expression, limited to one operation, that represents correspondence between positions and terms of an arithmetic sequence.

DEBB358BEDA84F1B9DB26EAB5E386A1D.description: Describe a rule, limited to one operation, that expresses correspondence between positions and terms of an arithmetic sequence.

05AC9E6DF53A40878683B0BBFE151E46.description: Describe the graph of an arithmetic sequence as a straight line.

121E607A0F5248A5BD5CC9300A5C6AF2.description: Represent one-to-one correspondence between positions and terms of an arithmetic sequence in a table of values and on a coordinate grid.

D55E500951924620B8BC51C0A19A0332.description: Each term of an arithmetic sequence corresponds to a natural number indicating position in the sequence.

B86EC8041A3E4B07A7CD048A5151349C.description: An algebraic expression can describe the relationship between the positions and terms of an arithmetic sequence.

C5EC6E2B2EA142B0ADAB31F0FC5653EF.description: Points representing an arithmetic sequence on a coordinate grid fit on a straight line.

DF012B076A5A4490A72719A8141259C5.description: A table of values representing an arithmetic sequence lists the position in the first column or row and the corresponding term in the second column or row.

AA1737B6AD774FD69EA642D749EE769F.description: Students relate terms to position within an arithmetic sequence.

491B7D9AECF7489694121ABE391BE1D7.description: Patterns: Awareness of patterns supports problem solving in various situations.

12CBD438A6C842EF984B5CCCD582F3BF.description: Describe the rectangle with the least perimeter for a given area.

949404C52CDB499DA2F651441C635412.description: Compare the perimeters of various rectangles with the same area.

E3975F9F0308467BA135E7DCD0BB9304.description: Express the area of a rectangle using standard units given the lengths of its sides.

A80756519EA04E41A6614286498D0E5A.description: Estimate an area by comparing to a benchmark of a square centimetre or square metre.

60A5E4949BDC4C569B82361154FB3951.description: Justify the choice of square centimetres, square metres, or square kilometres as appropriate units to express various areas.

CCC34323A14D403EB21FA8826E5CD2DD.description: Express the relationship between square centimetres, square metres, and square kilometres.

AD81545B9EF243D990C567EBCC17848F.description: Relate a square centimetre to a square metre.

5E8BBD2DF5C64F0EAAB4C289D2097BEF.description: Relate a metre to a square metre.

5C6AE67DA2304B2F83BFC8B72B3CE955.description: Relate a centimetre to a square centimetre.

58CD0A5B2D4544E5A0028C270D9F269A.description: Rectangles with the same area can have different perimeters.

A990244651204AC2A846B5C6B10DD086.description: Area can be expressed in various units according to context and desired precision.

887B3B25EA0A4B2BAD7B017AC71E7538.description: Among all rectangles with the same area, the square has the least perimeter.

DFF75805B27E45AAAE6E6E2A9CC5C6AA.description: A square kilometre (km2) is an area equivalent to the area of a square measuring 1 kilometre by 1 kilometre.

82534D2490114509B14A12D7F7F32F45.description: A square metre (m2) is an area equivalent to the area of a square measuring 1 metre by 1 metre.

7A70CC6915A84D69891E51A2F0BE462F.description: A square centimetre (cm2) is an area equivalent to the area of a square measuring 1 centimetre by 1 centimetre.

68C56D955C144BF8BB67CD3A6A22714A.description: Area is expressed in the following standard units, derived from standard units of length: square centimetres, square metres and square kilometres.

E1C6467228674123B781FE62CB68EFBE.description: Students estimate and calculate area using standard units.

D89EB9FA19B741F9872B5E4FCCBF3E8B.description: Measurement: Attributes such as length, area, volume, and angle are quantified by measurement.

49CC67421B404983B750B7133238CAEF.description: Describe the location of the vertices of a polygon on a coordinate grid using coordinates.

9B0EE1356AC44A88A868B436F4C8A504.description: Model a polygon on a coordinate grid using coordinates to indicate the vertices.

62D7278F037A4B49820CAA3D259699B7.description: Describe the location of a point on a coordinate grid in relation to the location of another point using positional language.

A11D66F2E7A44C95933F8CF98AA4A400.description: Describe the location of a point on a coordinate grid using coordinates.

E6417E72C86E46E4B4E1362216F87178.description: Locate a point on a coordinate grid given the coordinates of the point.

2BC12CBBE4B24976A65B02ADF467C3E8.description: Location can be described precisely using a coordinate grid.

F921492F9FB649D5A9434AA2A7B3681E.description: Location can describe the position of shapes in space.

51E91232EBD34A5C840F8F060F272BF8.description: Positional language includes left, right, up and down.

416EA2970EA14E11B290FB4C054F2CB9.description: Coordinates are ordered pairs of numbers in which the first number indicates the distance from the vertical axis and the second number indicates the distance from the horizontal axis.

C9301443199D49A88E0AB8B8732D5423.description: Coordinate grids use coordinates to indicate the location of the point where the vertical and horizontal grid lines intersect.

F0E28EE1F7BB405F82CB0BC972E47A68.description: Students relate location to position on a grid.

607029130AF54B06A7D3BD02DA9F1ED6.description: Coordinate Geometry: Location and movement of objects in space can be communicated using a coordinate grid.

555AC91AC2F04FE9814548BF0DAABBC1.description: Classify 2-D shapes according to the number of reflection or rotation symmetries.

E4293F6CECAA4662B5A848BB414A32C1.description: Compare the number of reflection and rotation symmetries of a 2-D shape to the number of equal sides and angles.

021B5E2AB0154E64A23165A0763761B5.description: Describe the order of rotation symmetry of a 2-D shape.

25423698A451450987748C62E8CCC71A.description: Show the line of symmetry of a 2-D shape.

B5D80DA4BA154F69B0608A44166E0B33.description: Investigate symmetry in familiar 2-D and 3-D shapes using hands-on materials or digital applications.

B58F350B8DBF4DDE886C0DC5393E46C6.description: Recognize symmetry in First Nations, Mtis, and Inuit designs.

19871B7E732D4F3A9CDE05F104B09CB4.description: Symmetry is related to other geometric properties.

31E7A9641A6F4CAB94C63E33E5FE94D6.description: Symmetry can be created and can occur in nature.

97F632023065494E88EF32A3341F57CB.description: Symmetry is a property of shapes.

44AB275E7DF140E3A92324728BBB6D86.description: A circle has infinitely many reflection and rotation symmetries.

CFB5ABF3AE1B493788159316B782B113.description: In a regular polygon, the number of sides equals the number of reflection symmetries and the number of rotation symmetries.

86C820FF79AB444780E0775B264B88F9.description: Symmetry can be found in First Nations, Mtis, and Inuit designs, such as basket weaving, wampum belts, quilts, First Nations beadwork, Inuit beadwork, or Mtis floral beadwork and architecture such as tipis or longhouses.

A9D35012C2224FA88C1C23B68E3070C4.description: The straight line that connects a point with its image in the central symmetry passes through the centre of rotation.

63FF311713724AC883F4E97A13DC3255.description: Central symmetry is the rotational symmetry by 180.

011DDCBB44E54059BB4EE9EF749E9EC6.description: Order of rotation symmetry describes the number of times a shape coincides with itself within a rotation of 360 around its centre point.

1EBBC958E9B34ABC927A6EA65EDD0621.description: A 2-D shape has rotation symmetry if it exactly overlaps itself one or more times within a rotation of less than 360 around its centre point.

BD62216EB1944719890E8B6CDB81445C.description: A 3-D shape has reflection symmetry if there is a plane over which the shape reflects and the two halves exactly match.

5C212DC49D0045B6A6D9FB96B843047C.description: A 2-D shape has reflection symmetry if there is a straight line over which the shape reflects and the two halves exactly match.

FACAC38404574D83985CD798BF1E919C.description: Students investigate symmetry as a geometric property.

7DD3392FB1224F84A23C45E2D6B36FC3.description: Geometry: Shapes are defined and related by geometric attributes.

9F4AA49FEA014AB88C19AE692211ADAF.description: Solve problems using equations, limited to equations with one or two operations.

4B33C596A7A74AD092F212FAB80C6D43.description: Verify the solution to an equation by evaluating expressions on each side of the equation.

FFAB10DD4CCF4A2BB86A1085D77FCC32.description: Apply inverse operations to solve an equation, limited to equations with one or two operations.

4B3FC7872BA6446A8145AC983A0531D0.description: Investigate order of operations when performing inverse operations on both sides of an equation.

056456334D9148A7A8C455E906812D7D.description: Write equations involving one or two operations to represent a situation.

F2E1CEC5ACEC457699ED73623BCC56BC.description: Evaluate an algebraic expression by substituting a given number for the variable.

45E1E1A613734DF9A81E6D0B09D538C0.description: Write an algebraic expression involving one or two terms to describe an unknown value.

BD9066808BDB4DD5951015CABD4A8672.description: Recognize a product with a variable, a quotient with a variable, or a number as a single term.

9EB6D1BD2BAB4DB2AE08A9BDD41C3B68.description: Express the quotient of a variable and a number as a fraction.

72C9799D93BD442FA21001C8F634E358.description: Express the product of a number and a variable using a coefficient.

CFD1E5E51E1C468F8FAEA79F78A02021.description: Relate repeated addition of a variable to the product of a number and a variable.

157CE386D9DE4C19A13D84BAFD3B19A7.description: Evaluate numerical expressions involving addition or subtraction in parentheses according to the order of operations.

6F349CE9ED504BF0B8B6465694C2E9D5.description: The expressions on each side of an equation will be equal when evaluated using the correct solution.

7EE83F5C7F854678AF70C56732689871.description: Equality is preserved by applying inverse operations to algebraic expressions on each side of an equation.

D82B8A68E81A4C94BCB7C31B40EB773B.description: Algebraic expressions may be composed of one algebraic term or the sum of algebraic and constant terms.

3E73DA10F15643C1A120AD1936CAB59D.description: Algebraic expressions use variables to represent quantities of unknown value.

ACBAA8C11F13494993E25DAE77330C29.description: Parentheses change the order of operations in a numerical expression.

BBBD82F962424354B5ECAFBE1C3A2F3D.description: Numerical expressions represent a quantity of known value.

750D58B32DBF437B812F135C17E87213.description: The value of the variable obtained by solving an equation is the solution.

04A820DD40ED460E86347200B9F5FA9A.description: The process of applying inverse operations can be used to solve an equation.

A32C7F41D96441058454C7864ED4A455.description: A variable can be replaced by a given number in order to evaluate an expression.

289060B75C13412A912E36B1A71C7682.description: A constant term is a number.

434F5C2C34D64EA1847ADC8DD0ECAD31.description: An algebraic term is the product of a number, called a coefficient, and a variable.

D9D120BF30C7419BA2B6E81E7E00BB91.description: Quotients with variables are expressed using fraction notation.

3E08EB81ED0D4BE3A8B491B5DF9A8BBA.description: Products with variables are expressed without the multiplication sign.

0AB3834397D74FFE9469E86D4A9DE5A4.description: A variable can be interpreted as a specific unknown value and is represented symbolically with a letter.

897D759769274D7DB423653B37B0DD5A.description: Expressions that include variables are called algebraic expressions.

2972D41637224CDB956346D43ADFA837.description: The conventional order of operations includes performing operations in parentheses before other operations.

40ECA44BB202468E8CEB493A6A9B64C5.description: Numerical expressions with multiple operations may include parentheses to group numbers and operations.

76E5A39BAB4045DB8184CE1F24DEC55F.description: Students interpret numerical and algebraic expressions.

3DC9D68E4E2C44D4A72766229B087DF0.description: Algebra: Equations express relationships between quantities.

2CD18B106F6344AF94AEDDF202E9BACF.description: Express, symbolically, the same part-whole relationship as a ratio, fraction, decimal, and percentage.

D2E01F444A3A4F65A3D30E8563701A40.description: Express part-part ratios and part-whole ratios of the same whole to describe various situations.

3E0A749BCD2547AFAE10F523F8E923BB.description: Fractions, decimals, ratios, and percentages can represent the same part-whole relationship.

F08217EC442441AEAB7F598ACACBB471.description: A ratio is a comparison of two quantities in a specific situation.

3A1C3F7F92F34EBA960B86852D873ABC.description: A percentage represents a part-whole ratio that compares a quantity to 100.

9E40B381581D494CB0BD74E8F66441AE.description: A ratio can be expressed with a fraction or with a colon.

7DEAD3462C5A4616A90E62656E5B8494.description: A ratio can express part-part or part-whole relationships between two countable or measurable quantities.

06B656F17A98456691DE97B3987ACB90.description: Students employ ratios to represent relationships between quantities.

4CE19701DFA84F3DB7A0C4C91C119913.description: Solve problems requiring addition and subtraction of fractions with common denominators, including improper fractions and mixed numbers.

7E5865E7E74F42DCAAE4EE7A2F36F1B4.description: Add and subtract fractions with common denominators within 100, including improper fractions and mixed numbers.

AE5E3678BD5641A1848B405DD933F848.description: Compare strategies for adding or subtracting improper fractions to strategies for adding or subtracting mixed numbers.

13600F3D67E34A2BB49D6142532B3B13.description: Express the composition or decomposition of fractions with common denominators as a sum or difference.

98B794363D6C4B8AAF650B44D7D18C78.description: Investigate the composition and decomposition of a quantity within 1 using unit fractions.

DE7B858288C5423E98CB7F659BAE8513.description: Properties for addition and subtraction of natural numbers apply to fractions.

FE61D6B86ECB467799E47B375D592897.description: Fractions with common denominators are multiples of the same unit fraction.

309EBA63F6BF4BC5BDF912C04833A5D3.description: Fractions greater than one can be added or subtracted as mixed numbers or improper fractions.

1E57120F1EB14F3B85CA36533120CB30.description: Addition and subtraction of fractions with common denominators does not change the unit fraction from which they are composed.

B4AE84CD61BE478296564DDE6F4BB47E.description: Fractions with common denominators can be composed or decomposed to model the change in a quantity of unit fractions.

512965BE8DDE467AAB7B63B5E8DF80FB.description: Students add and subtract fractions with common denominators.

4986DF4B756A4178B7D360CA9F75EFEA.description: Compare fractions, including improper fractions and mixed numbers, to benchmarks of 0 1/2, and 1.

E2FE0AC2E29949A09844C0BDB42EB8CA.description: Express an improper fraction as a mixed number and vice versa

919F8FF130BE4B09A9E1014A49F3FC74.description: Express improper fractions and mixed numbers symbolically.

EA60F7DF277F4EF78732AB7FB5459E02.description: Model fractions, including improper fractions and mixed numbers, using quantities, lengths, and areas.

FB69733E41264AC1A46019E30191D514.description: Count beyond 1 using fractions with the same denominator.

C548D618BF164C5489D9902C7D855953.description: Relate fractions, improper fractions, and mixed numbers to their positions on the number line.

BC3E30FE6E19468DA47462C785C1F340.description: Improper fractions and mixed numbers that represent the same number are associated with the same point on the number line.

1F2AFF14C8134AF899128CFF96AC03DE.description: Fractions allow counting and measuring between whole quantities.

453C2C10F39E46EDAB09A484BC766F3D.description: A mixed number of the form A b/c, composed of a number of wholes, A, and a fractional part, b/c,  can represent an improper fraction.

3D568A8B269B479CBC23C8988459F8DA.description: Natural numbers can be expressed as improper fractions with a denominator of 1.

DAF9735CCDC8491EA5F85792F791FA12.description: An improper fraction has a numerator that is greater than its denominator.

DA570728297E4F57A02F53CFDBF562F9.description: A fraction can represent quantities greater than one.

A59F13A2105A4B6E8E89770F3F22DD62.description: Solve problems using multiplication and division of natural numbers.

858EBEF7EBEA436488F2D732F0A4FF36.description: Assess the reasonableness of a product or quotient using estimation.

CD21ED51DB4249A1AB052AC978BCEF86.description: Express a quotient with or without a remainder according to context.

43A1D83713D44D0AA96E0FE22C66CE40.description: Divide 3-digit by 1-digit natural numbers using standard algorithms.

26173D0B26284CFCADEA6BD60B59CE4A.description: Multiply up to 3-digit by 2-digit natural numbers using standard algorithms.

F0260A06CF3C4268AB6F77600DE9A691.description: Explain the standard algorithms for multiplication and division of natural numbers.

BBCAC4CB57D94F04AFE80A8BE0883AD0.description: Standard algorithms are efficient procedures for multiplication and division.

952763015BFF463AB4FF55EDE685C116.description: Multiplication and division of numbers with many digits is facilitated by standard algorithms.

94D66966A3324C30B084AE1D03B4DE57.description: Students multiply and divide natural numbers within 100 000, including with standard algorithms.

08F38EDDB5B7448FAE32D9DA6FA6CABB.description: Determine factors of natural numbers using divisibility tests.

62592DE2CE63441C9D43E6D5195971C4.description: Investigate divisibility by natural numbers to 10, including 0.

8506C77F3F074488908DE3DEE29827BB.description: A number is divisible by another number if it can be divided with a remainder of 0.

93151A4BF7F94126912A886DA7E8B9EA.description: Division by zero is not possible.

039356BF6B384165AC46B6C91F4BCEF6.description: A divisibility test can be used to determine factors of a natural number.

F33260DF9730401195CC2FEB10AD736A.description: Students determine divisibility of natural numbers.

CB5A431D5BD847B4A0E832ECD5643F23.description: Solve problems using addition and subtraction, including problems involving money.

81594F0891664EE4A1DDFD03F6577527.description: Assess the reasonableness of a sum or difference using estimation.

3A3A47BC07364D289E929319233642DE.description: Add and subtract numbers, including decimal numbers, using standard algorithms.

3810C91372954D9EAE95E7DA72160445.description: Addition and subtraction of numbers with many digits is facilitated by standard algorithms.

112C40992C3842679B44BDC7A1E6DAF9.description: Standard algorithms are efficient procedures for addition and subtraction.

5BD251E9BF4E464CB050FFF21EA4F229.description: Students add and subtract within 1 000 000, including decimal numbers to thousandths, using standard algorithms.

9F3736FE813D43E291832BF3DEF2151D.description: Round numbers, including decimal numbers, to various places according to context.

595C831895D0400A8935EB9213822068.description: Express the relationship between two numbers, including decimal numbers, using <, >, or =.

B47DA626C4234241869334C46A261F3C.description: Compare and order numbers, including decimal numbers.

E6ACAB0A7048421C81CE721411FEABB0.description: Determine a decimal number between any two other decimal numbers.

058B46D1F3064EC48294854E7103B6B7.description: Relate a decimal number to its position on the number line.

9C4792AB1FBF4BCABD280C4016EAF097.description: Express numbers within 10 000 000, including decimal numbers to thousandths, using words and numerals.

0F8E03EFA6F74C60B03962D1A056240B.description: Relate the names of place values that are the same number of places to the left and right of the ones place.

D17EDE8DED0645308EBB2ECD26A602CD.description: Place value symmetry extends infinitely to the left and right of the ones place.

C8C69D0E4015444FB06ABE7A62F6DE35.description: There are infinitely many decimal numbers between any two decimal numbers.

A8EE2BDF5FBB41009C70A2DC78BF98AE.description: A zero in the rightmost place of a decimal number does not change the value of the number.

0DF5D1A577EA4A619D85CEC96D5A49F3.description: A number expressed with more decimal places is more precise.

5BF3B1FA7A8440F2912E8A0AD85F1BD4.description: Students analyze patterns in place value.

24D849290A0A4CAEA731C551002EE62E.description: Number: Quantity is measured with numbers that enable counting, labelling, comparing, and operating.
